title: 109_hr5292
content: The United States policy aims to deny the Cuban regime financial resources that threaten national security, interests, and the environment. It also seeks to deter foreign investments that could enhance Cuba's petroleum resources. Additionally, the exclusion of certain aliens who contribute to Cuba's petroleum development is addressed in the Cuban Liberty and Democratic Solidarity Act of 1996. The Secretary of State will deny visas and exclude certain aliens from the US who invest over $1,000,000 in Cuba's petroleum development. Waivers may be granted for medical or litigation reasons. Definitions for "develop" and "investment" are provided in the section. The amendment made by this section applies to aliens seeking admission to the United States on or after the date of the enactment of this Act, regarding investments in Cuba's petroleum development. The text chunk "SEC. 3. IMPOSITION OF SANCTIONS." is a concise statement indicating the imposition of sanctions. The President must impose sanctions on individuals who invest over $1,000,000 in Cuba's petroleum development. Sanctions include restricting Export-Import Bank assistance and prohibiting specific exports. The United States Government is prohibited from issuing specific licenses or permissions to export goods or technology to sanctioned persons under various acts. Financial institutions may be prohibited from providing loans exceeding $10,000,000 to sanctioned persons unless for humanitarian purposes. Sanctions may also be imposed on financial institutions that are sanctioned persons. Prohibitions on financial institutions include restrictions on being designated as a primary dealer in US Government debt instruments and serving as a repository of government funds. Sanctions may also include procurement restrictions by the US Government. The United States Government may impose procurement sanctions on sanctioned persons, prohibiting the procurement of goods or services from them. The term "person" includes foreign subsidiaries of sanctioned individuals.
